results.title: Stickmen
results.creator_credit: Hamish Rothwell, Michelle Turner, Film 2, New Zealand On Air, New Zealand Film Commission and Stickfilms
results.brief_description: Sticks, or pool, means more than life to Jack (Robbie Magasiva), Wayne (Scott Wills) and Thomas (Paolo Rotondo) - it can even override sex. In fact, “pub pool is the perfect game…conflict, drama, thrill of the chase, strategy and a cliff-hanger ending”. What more could you want? As best mates, the trio spend most of their spare time hustling at Dave’s Bar for a bit of a laugh and some money on the side until one night they are asked to enter into a high stakes tournament run by the local crime boss “Daddy” (Enrico Mammarella). Their pool-playing lives suddenly changes - as the stakes get higher so trouble seems to follow and all three are faced with the prospect of doing what Daddy asks or else! But more than anything else, the “Stickmen” want to win. Humor, sex, violence, romance and pool blend together to make this a quirky and upbeat film in the tradition of “Lock stock and two smoking barrels” and also is director Hamish Rothwell’s first feature film. Cast includes Anne Nordhaus, Simone Xessell, John Leigh, Kirk Torrance, Luanne Gordon.

results.title: Steamboat Willie
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Steamboat Willie is the first animated film to use synchronised sound, and the first Mickey Mouse cartoon ever released. Mickey appears as a crew member on a riverboat which is captained by big bad Pete. Minnie Mouse is the passenger who joins Mickey as he uses various props as musical instruments. Animation by Ub Iwerks.

results.title: Squizzy Taylor
results.creator_credit: Kevin Dobson, Roger Le Mesurier and Roger Simpson
results.brief_description: Set in the 1920’s, in Melbourne, and covering the life and experiences of the enterprising and notorious criminal Squizzy Taylor. Stars Jackie Weaver, Alan Cassell and David Atkins.

results.title: Spy kids
results.creator_credit: Robert Rodriguez, Elizabeth Avellan, Troublemaker Studios and Dimension Films
results.brief_description: Gregorio Cortez (Antonio Banderas) and Ingrid Cortez (Carla Gugino) are a happily married couple living with their two children, Carmen and Juni, in a seemingly regular existence except for the fact that Gregorio and Ingrid are both professional spies. When their parents are kidnapped, Carmen and Juni are required to put their sibling rivalry aside and band together (hoping they have inherited some of their parents’ skills) in order to save them. Using a plethora of high tech gadgets and computer-generated stunts, “Spy kids” makes for good family fun, with a well-paced narrative and amusing script. Scottish actor Alan Cumming revels in the role of Fegan Floop a mastermind of devilry who aims to bring down the Cortez couple and rule the world. The aesthetic of the film overflows with lurid colour, in particular the elaborate setting of Floop’s castle with his peculiar army of plasticine-like figures and thumb-men. The film marks a shift in genre for director Robert Rodriguez (El Mariachi, Desperado, From dusk till dawn) whose previous efforts have been films of a more violent and bloody nature. Also starring Terri Hatcher, Robert Patrick and Tony Shaloub.

results.title: Speedy
results.creator_credit: Ted Wilde and Harold Lloyd Corporation
results.brief_description: Harold Lloyd’s last silent work and the only one shot entirely on location in New York, tells of Harold ‘Speedy’ Swift’s efforts to save the last horse-drawn streetcar line in New York from the machinations of some traction magnates. He has to surmount all sorts of obstacles to do so including getting ‘Babe’ Ruth to his baseball on time. The end-of-an-era plot line must have partly reflected Lloyd’s feelings towards the introduction of sound to the movies. With an orchestral score performed by The Live Cinema Orchestra. Cast also includes Ann Christy and Burt Woodruffe.

results.title: Spaceborne
results.brief_description: Rarely seen footage from NASA missions shows the excitement of man’s first ventures into space. The editing and music transform the images into an exciting visual experience. No spoken commentary.

results.title: Songs from the second floor
results.creator_credit: Roy Andersson, Lisa Alwert, Roy Andersson Filmproduktion, Nordisk Film-och TV-Fond and Danmarks Radio
results.brief_description: On the eve of the millenium in an unidentified west European city, strange events begin to unfold. At first they are strictly personal and individual: a businessman has to fire his staff in order to satisfy the logic of the free market; a magician’s trick backfires and he begins to saw a man in half; a lost immigrant is set upon violently by a passing group of strangers. Soon the world around the city itself begins to fall apart. There is an inexplicable and seemingly neverending traffic jam; board meetings descend into panic when the buildings themselves begin to move; the souls of the dead begin to rise. In the midst of all of this there is Karl, a failed businessman who has set his factory alight and who argues incessantly with his mute poet son who has gone mad. “Songs from the Second Floor”, filmed almost entirely of single take long shots, is a surrealist black comedy about the collapse of capitalism that uses the rhetoric of the free market and of liberalism itself to refract back a world in which competition, exploitation, and surplus has led to the devaluation of all human relationships, aspirations and commitments. One moment moving us with highly emotional scenes of alienation and loss, the director Roy Andersson then juxtaposes those moments with scenes of wicked and almost blasphemous black humour (an old Army General celebrating his centenary embarrasses the guests by calling out for Goering; a fast-talking businessman throws away crucifixes in disgust when he realises Christianity no longer sells). Influenced by the nightmare visions of Kafka, the audacious experimentation of the Theatre of the Absurd and by the director’s own experiences in framing and directing highly stylised TV commercials, “Songs from the Second Floor” is one of the most striking, idiosyncratic and ultimately disturbing of millenium visions. In this world of mirrors and endless windows reflecting and opening up to only increasing folly, the fire and brimstone of the Christian Armageddon is replaced by the insane selfishness, greed and panic which greets the capitalist vision of the end of the world. The excellent music score is by former Abba performer, Benny Andersson. (Awards: Winner of the Special Jury Prize, Cannes Film Festival, 2000)

results.title: Song of Ceylon
results.creator_credit: GPO Film Unit, John Grierson and Basil Wright
results.brief_description: A poetic interpretation of the life and customs of the people of Ceylon, showing the contrast between the culture of the Singalese of the island, and the western economic outlook. One of the most famous of the GPO Film Unit’s productions, this film helped to build the reputation of the British documentary film movement. ‘The Song of Ceylon’ is in four sections, 1. The Buddha, 2. The Virgin island, 3. The Voice of commerce, 4. The Apparel of God. Sponsored by the Ceylon Tea Propaganda Board. Music by Walter Leigh. Photographed by Basil Wright.

results.title: Solas
results.creator_credit: Benito Zambrano, Antonio P Perez and Maestranza Films
results.brief_description: Thirtysomething Maria lives alone in a squalid quarter of a nameless Spanish city, having fled the rural home of her violent, alcoholic father and long-suffering mother. Embittered and depressed by her family life, her experiences with men, her menial job and her recent discovery that she is pregnant, she finds her only solace in alcohol. After her father is admitted to a nearby hospital she begrudgingly lets her mother stay with her while he recuperates. Although her daughter disdains her for silently tolerating years of abuse by her husband, Maria’s mother is nevertheless warm and loving, and does all she can to brighten her daughter’s life. She also befriends a neighbour in the same apartment block, a desperately lonely old man who quickly becomes attached to her and gives her the respect and affection she never experienced with her husband. Slowly and tentatively, mother and daughter begin to set aside their practiced antagonism and repair the lines of communication in their relationship. Buoyed by her newfound understanding of her mother and her own budding relationship with her elderly neighbour, Maria starts to gain new hope for her future. Highly successful in its home country, “Solas” is sensitively directed, never sliding into sentimentality, and is filled with standout performances from its small cast. Cast includes Ana Fernandez, Maria Galiana and Carlos Alvarez-Novoa. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Snows of Aorangi
results.brief_description: Shows champions Hans Bohny, Harvey Clifford, and Peter Lawlor on a ski run on the slopes of New Zealand’s highest mountain, Mt Cook or Aorangi - “the cloud piercer” as it is known by the Maoris. Includes spectacular scenes of a snow-storm, an avalanche, and strange ice formations.
